commentText: Just want to say thank you Peter.  My mom loves your videos.  She has dementia.  We are Mennonites so I started showing her your series on Amish and Mennonites.  She appreciates (as do I) your openness to the culture and how you respect all the people and places you visit.   I have enjoyed sitting with her watching your videos.  She has visited at least twelve countries and many cities in the US and this helps her recall some of her life that she usually can't remember.  She doesn't understand the concept of watching YT videos on smart tv's, so she is constantly asking if it is time for the show where 'that nice man' interviews people.  Big hug!!

commentText: I'm Dutch and the unspoken rule of the church being the tallest building is definitely still alive. I live in Utrecht and the Dom tower is roughly 350ft tall. There are plans to make a 400ft tower in a new part of the city over the river and you best believe there is a lot of hubbub about it. The council has decided that outside of the historic center, it's allowed to build taller than the Dom (which still caused a lot of commotion), but no more than twice the average height of the buildings in that area. Inside the historic center, you cannot build taller than the Dom.

commentText: At the 27:53 mark, during the inquiry into whether AI could be held responsible for a teenager's suicide, the individual in red promptly affirmed with such self-confidence that it was an isolated incident. He then immediately redirected the discussion from the gravity of a human life lost to the assertion, "If we do not prevail in the AI competition, another global power such as China will." This viewpoint is particularly concerning given a recent discussion I coincidentally observed on today's episode of the Megyn Kelly show. The program featured the teenager's parents, Matt and Maria Raine, and their attorney, Jay Edelson, who presented substantial evidence indicating that such incidents are not isolated. The episode explored the tragic circumstances surrounding their son, Adam Raine's suicide, alleging that ChatGPT incited the act. The discussion also addressed the inherent risks of the platform, the ongoing legal action against the company, Sam Altman's response to these events, the disturbing interaction between ChatGPT and Adam, and the parents' dedication to increasing awareness about the dangers associated with this technology.

commentText: I don't need to pretend that I visit a coffee store for "personal touch" service, wait in queue and hear the 3 conversations before I can order my drink, then finally hear the "cha-ching" from cashier machine. With Luckin, I just order and pay on my app under 1 minute, look at the estimated time that my coffee will be ready, walk to the store and it is there sitting on the counter for me to collect. I don't have a say a single word to anybody. I like that kind of effiiency. Luckin has proven to be a huge success in Singapore from the very first day it launched. The frustration with using the app is just a one-time thing for some customers who are still clueless about how the digital age is changing consumer experience. Very soon most of them will come around.  Remember "raising your hand to hail a cab is much easier than downloading the Uber app!"?  For every cup of coffee that Starbucks sell per store, Luckin will sell three, minus the cashier.

commentText: as someone who was offered a job in the tech sector in austin, i can tell you one of the main reasons they didnt attract talent to move there is they tried paying standard Texas wages in a city with 2x the median texas cost of living. i was earning $42/hr when they offered me my job, and the offer was for $35/hr with no relocation assistance. the apartments in austin were only like $300/month less than the ones i had on the west coast.... suffice it to say i stayed where i was and now earn $45/hr. the big names in tech tried to cheap out by going to texas, but austin's not worth moving to unless you pay west coast wages. why would i move to a place where it's hot, i have to run constant A/C, i cant walk anywhere and im 5 hours from anything fun, oh and all for a pay cut. yea no thanks.

commentText: TX born & raised but spent a fair amount of time on the west coast & pnw. Only reason I came back was family. Outdoor rec is so much better elsewhere. Climates in general much more moderate elsewhere. The historically lower cost of living here is negated by comparatively lower wages. I understand why people leave Cali, OR, WA and I understand why Austin sounded good on paper 5-10 years ago. I see very few reasons why people would want to move here now. It's a tough place to be even for someone who has family and knows most of the escapes. I imagine being here alone and used to a more moderate climate would suck.

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.

commentText: No one will ever be able to beat Silicon Valley in Software but Austin could become the America's Shenzhen when it comes to hardware. Samsung is building a semiconductor plant in the Austin area, Apple makes Macbook pros there (some of it's only US manufacturing), Dell makes Servers in Austin, and of Course Tesla and SpaceX both do lots of hardware stuff there. Austin has far more cheap land, cheap labor, and cheap electricity than California making it a far more desirable destination for hardware.

commentText: As someone who grew up in Texas and lived in Austin in the 90s, I 100% saw this coming. It's hot, full of bugs, and there isn't F all to do nature wise compared to a state like California. You can drive eight hours in any direction and there's hardly a change of weather or scenery. In California you drive one or two hours in a different direction and you are in the mountains, forest, desert, beaches, etc. then there is the illusion of freedom. Texas is pretty much 100% privately owned land. Try finding a dirt road to just drive down and ride a motorcycle or go shoot your guns. California while it has some of the worst and most restrictive gun laws in the country, outside of LA or Marin county there is quite a bit of freedom. You see a dirt road in the mountains and It's likely government or public land and you can drive down there in your jeep and go shoot your guns smoking a doobie and if a park ranger sees you he's likely just to wave.

commentText: I'm a Texas native now living in California and so I think I'm qualified to give an opinion on this. Austin is a great place (the greatest city in Texas, if you ask me). But like much of Texas, it's hotter than hell. I'll take the weather in San Francisco, San Jose, Los Angeles, or San Diego any day over Texas. Second, Texas has nowhere near the amount of natural beauty as California. Period. It's not even close. Finally, although Austin is left-leaning, for some people, Texas politics in general are much too far to the right (even for moderates).

commentText: If CA and NY were their own independent countries, they would automatically be among the top 10 nations globally in terms of GDP.  NY and CA didnâ€™t get to achieve powerhouse status  magically or overnight.  Massive infrastructure investments over decades, huge capital investments pouring into those states daily, top notch med schools/hospitals/research facilities/global law firms/ad agencies /etc., bar none the best financial institutions and resources anywhere and magnets for the best and brightest to continue a tradition of innovation.  Few others can compete at that level.  And no, Iâ€™m not from either state.  Just being real.

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.
videoDescription: Austin saw the biggest price drop in homes in the United States. So what's happening to the city that was luring Silicon Valley?
commentText: I grew up in the Bay Area and lived in Dallas for a year. I visited Austin, San Antonio, Houston, Galveston. Iâ€™ll never set foot in Texas again if I can possibly help it. I knew a lot of people who moved there from the Bay Area would regret it. There just isnâ€™t enough to do within easy access for enough of the year. In the Bay Area, you can take a day trip to go skiiing from December until March. You can sail or kayak or windsurf the rest of the year from scores of launches along the Bay and all along the Delta. You can comfortably hike year round, play tennis outdoors, bike in Golden Gate Park. In Dallas, I couldnâ€™t do anything outdoors during the summertime. It was 90 degrees at night. I know Austin wasnâ€™t any more comfortable. Stanford and Cal are two of the best universities in the world, creating a stimulating, invigorating environment. Unfortunately, Oakland has lost its professional sports franchises, but you still have the 49ers, Giants, Warriors, Sharks and Earthquakes, all the major sports. Austin? None of them. The food is better, world famous in San Francisco. More variety, fresh fruit and vegetables year round, pretty cheap too. Thereâ€™s just no comparison in my mind. Sure real estate might have been cheaper, and probably still is, but I donâ€™t want to stay indoors looking at the walls all day. More space just means more space to clean. A bigger garden means more weeds to pull. A riding lawn mower is not as much fun as a kayak. People severely misjudged what life in Texas is like.  So Iâ€™ll tell you. it sucks. Austin and the surrounding Hill Country are the nicest parts, but Texas as a whole sucks, especially with the current gubmint.

commentText: Around the world, office spaces are sitting half-empty. With faster internet (6G on the horizon) and better tech, working from home isnâ€™t just easyâ€”itâ€™s smart.  Corporates know it too. Theyâ€™re quietly shutting down entire floors and buildings to cut costs. Where I work, we had 7 satellite buildings onceâ€¦ now just 2 remain. Thatâ€™s 5 buildings goneâ€”previously home to 5,000+ people.  We now have to book a desk 3 weeks in advanceâ€¦ but guess what? Even with all the seat booking apps, many desks stay empty. Mondays and Fridays? Ghost towns. No booking neededâ€”just walk in and sit wherever you want.  Letâ€™s be realâ€”WfH isnâ€™t a phase the corporates knownit too. It is the future. And itâ€™s already here.

commentText: I remember when I started at Dell in Round Rock.  It was the only thing around, surrounded by fields of cows and a small neighborhood or two.  Back then  there were just 3 buildings!   Then suddenly we had a walmart and an HEB and then TOLL ROADS...that was the beginning of the end haha.   Then we kept growing and growing like someone was force-stuffing a goose for that tasty foie gras.    MY RENT for a 2 bedroom place just a mile away was $450 a month..  I can't imagine now.     I remmber the Austin bus was free in 88.  I went everywhere, man.

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.
videoDescription: Austin saw the biggest price drop in homes in the United States. So what's happening to the city that was luring Silicon Valley?
commentText: As a silicon valley born and raised resident, I kept laughing at the "Austin is the next Silicon Valley" tripe everyone spewed years ago.  You can't replicate Stanford, Cal, Davis, etc. education in the bay with Texas.  It just doesn't work.  The culture of Texas doesn't allow for diverse people to come together and make new things.  The city itself is unbelievably hot, humid, and lacks any real diversity.  Now I've seen a ton of poeple coming back and they are so upset they sold their homes and now are struggling to get back in.

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.

commentText: As an Austinite from the place Portland stole "Keep ______ Weird," I found it easy to relocate to NYC and LA with no real culture change except for rent prices. So, it doesn't surprise me that the scavengers fleeing these cities to live their tech libertarian dreams found beating my city into submission even less possible. ğŸ˜‚

videoTitle: Silicon Valley Moved to Austin. Then Regretted It.
videoDescription: Austin saw the biggest price drop in homes in the United States. So what's happening to the city that was luring Silicon Valley?
commentText: It's true that the shifts in work arrangements are creating some very real ripples, and we're seeing that play out right here in Dallas. It's truly disheartening to hear about people you know facing the difficult decision of selling their homes, sometimes at a lower price than they purchased them for, all to relocate closer to their company's office.  Many employers are indeed making it clear that a return to in-office work is becoming a requirement, and for those who had moved further out for the flexibility of remote work, this can present a significant challenge. It forces a tough choice between their current living situation and their job security.

videoTitle: â‚¹1 CR Package After Clearing CPA ğŸ˜±ğŸ˜± #kushallodha #shorts #ca #cpa #shortvideo #cafoundation
commentText: It's not possible to complete the full Chartered Accountancy (CA) course in just one year. The CA course, including Foundation, Intermediate, and Final levels, typically takes a minimum of 4.5 to 5 years to complete. This includes the required articleship training period of three years. Even for graduates entering through the direct entry route, the minimum duration is 4.5 years.  Here's a more detailed breakdown:  Foundation Level: 6 months Intermediate Level: 8-10 months Articleship Training: 3 years Final Level: 6-12 months While some students might be able to accelerate their studies by studying intensely, passing exams quickly, and potentially completing the final level in one year after clearing the intermediate level, this would be an exception rather than the norm. The CA course requires a significant amount of time for theoretical learning,

commentText: I'm 57. I got hit with a lay off after nine years.  I did the on line crap and got no where.  I drove to a temp service and instantly got an interview the next day and got hired on the spot.  The place is less than seven miles from my house.  If you're serious about getting a job then look for a temp service close to you and physically go to it.  Companies go to them for people to hire as temps so they can simply call them if you don't end up working out.  You work as a temp for a while and if you prove yourself you get hired after a period of time.  I was only out of work for like a week and a half.  I make five bucks less per hour but I did finish paying off my truck so no car payment helps.

commentText: My boss's husband got let go from his executive job of 19 years. It's the only job he's ever had. He has no other job experience, is in his mid 40s, and the last time he went on a job interview was 2005. He got a good severance, but it will run out and he has had zero leads. "Laid off" used to mean when a company took you off the payroll temporarily to be recalled when business picked back up. These are layoffs. They are firings but we think that term is too harsh and judgmental. His resume is two paragraphs long. The first paragraph was working for his dad's plumbing company. I feel bad for him. Men of a certain age were raised to believe that you are a bum if you're unemployed. Two kids in college, and his wife makes about 25% of his former income. He's spiraling pretty bad, came by our work the other day about 10 am smelling like alcohol. I don't really believe that there is a path to career safety anymore.

commentText: So check this out. I am high volume recruiter for a popular retail chain.  I am required to fill 15 positions weekly minimum.  They just cut our hours to 32 hours a week indefinitely.  They also have fired several of my team mates and given me their work. I am still required to fill 15 positions within that 32 hour window for the same hourly rate (no overtime).  All of this is happening while our client has told us that they will no longer be posting new positions in half of our territories and our contract with the client is up in 2026.  I have about 60 openings that I have to fill. If I fill 15 each week, and they are only posting 4 or 5 new ones weekly or biweekly, how long until I work myself out of a job?  The irony is that the better I am at my job, the faster I will be laid off. If I underperform, then I will also be laid off in not too long.  Best case scenario I last until the end of the contract in 10 months and then get laid off with the entire team.  Damned if I do, Damned if I don't.  It's quite comical honestly.

commentText: As a millennial, with 8 years of professional experience in tech with 17 years of hobbyist experience, it is shit for us as well. I applied to 1,457 jobs before I landed a job with a local startup in a non-booming city. When i say startup, I mean me and the owner. That's it. I had to take this massive risk just to ensure I could pay rent after unemployment ran out here in the US. The best advice I can give is to do 2 things. Keep going, and get out into nature when you are not applying for jobs. Take a bus to go somewhere to hike. Get away from people as much as you can and refresh yourself.   Then try and find local job postings for SMALL businesses. And I mean small. Big tech will replace lower end employees faster than small mom and pop places who care about people. Aim to have enough, not excess. Learn to be content, not grinding. You will find happiness moment to moment, not in large clumps. And remember, when you eventually get something, be damn proud of yourself because it is fucking rough out there. Work hard, get into nature, and be at peace my friends. Hoping you all the best.

videoTitle: Why Gen Z Graduates Are in Crisis

commentText: As a German product architect and senior software engineer, I am almost too annoyed to even say this anymore - but I will do so once more, so that some people may learn the truth:  it is NOT AI which is taking so many jobs. Our biggest clients all work in manufacturing, as we write SAP software, which is used throughtout most of the German manufacturing and automotive industry (and many more). As I am in charge of our AI development projects myself, and have even implemented the proof of concept AI basis using keras on tensorflow for our data mining AIs while using a locally hosted LLM for our LLM-based project proof, I know AI and I know the technology.  However, in none of these corporations you could claim that AI is being used in a production-ready context. We (as a thirdparty SAP-based software supplier) are way ahead of other competitors in the same field, as we have a few AI products already ready for use. However, those products are the only ones our customers have ever seen in their automation and system context. And to this day I have to essentially always start from 0, when talking to any customer about AI.  No, the industry IS NOT USING AI IN PRODUCTION. Corporations are using "AI" as a neat excuse for not hiring because their business is just so bad these days (which they tell us often, when we suggest large-scale projects as we did before Covid). First all corporations blamed covid for their bad numbers, then it was the Ukraine war and now it is AI. The reason changes but the effect is the same: A bad economic recession and the current scapegoat is "AI automation".  So please, when you hear a corporation is not hiring because they automated the position using AI, just know that they are not hiring because they simply cannot afford to pay you, as their business is going slowly right now. To this day I have not seen even one AI product in production - and our smallest customer has around 10k employees worldwide. So if even they are not using AI in production - who is!?  ---------------------------------  One more comment: And don't forget the irony, that so many people claim AI will be taking developer jobs. If I knew how, I would automate half my work in home-office and simply be payed the same for less effort. But no, AI is so damn stupid that it is like a self-writing wikipedia, but barely anything more. Just today I was using AI for reading up on a specific python framework's documentation, and the AI gave me a stupid suggestion on which API to use for a specific use case. The example the AI (claude 4) gave me already contained another API method which could be used instead, and made everything else unnecessary. But - being a stupid AI - I had to tell the AI exactly that, after which it obviously responded with "blablabla you are totally correct blablabla". So even though as a product architect on this subject, I am also the leading dev. on everything AI, I still did not find any way to get the AI to write useful code for us. Because I essentially have to tell the AI everything I told students, when I was teaching at a German university over 10 years ago. It's frustrating and makes no sense to even try - just hire someone who knows these things, instead of trying to "educate" an AI every time you see it doing some nonsense BS. Because no static prompt you can give the bot, will actually make it stick to your rules, as it arbitrarily ignores them.   So no - AIs are not going to take any complex or engineering jobs. But it will take jobs/tasks related to art or entertainment. Because in these jobs failure is not hard, but "only" results in a less satisfying customer experience, instead of a total production or process failure.

commentText: I have been very fortunate to get my career started in IT right before AI and the job market went to shit. Iâ€™m 26. However, I will attribute my success to a few factors. 1. Insane luck 2. Being in the right place at the right time 3. Connections 4. I worked part time for several years prior, so I was able to earn skills while completing my college degree. The sad thing is a lot of my peers were told â€œjust do your schooling, and a job will be handed to youâ€ this was not really the case ever, but it was easier to keep applying and the numbers eventually came in your favour. Nowadays, my peers had no connections, no work experience besides their degree and they graduated right when AI boomed and the economy went downhill. Even without AI, the over reliance on nepotism is a not so talked about factor on why some people get jobs easier than those who donâ€™t.

commentText: I have a nephew in a small town in Kentucky who just graduated high school and decided to go into trade school for HVAC. He starts in a few days and said that his class has over 150 people in it and they had to split it into morning and evening classes. I think trades are great but I believe we are over saturating them like  we did with white collar jobs. The median income for an HVAC tech in his area is 18-22 an hour, which is not enough to thrive off of. I'm worried for him, and others his age. The issue is a broken system and deregulation in just about all fields. We should not just aspire to survive.

commentText: I explained the problem of creative destruction with AI to my boss one lunch. I went through how in the Industrial Revolution, many cottage industries were destroyed but those jobs were reclaimed by the industries that grew from the destruction. And I explained that with AI, there were very few jobs being actually made with this new technology - and he just tells me "don't worry about it." That phrase may as well be the tagline management when it comes to the job market - it tells you that everyone is just asleep at the wheel and if you lose your job to AI then it sucks to suck. That tells you all you need to know about how people are addressing this screwed job market.

videoTitle: Gen Z Is Getting Priced Out of Their Own Country
videoDescription: Gen Z is Getting Priced Out of Their Own Country At 24, I make $125000 as a software engineer in New York City, what most ...
commentText: Expats with strong currencies ruin local economies, I've acknowledged this repeatedly. But honestly, moving from NYC to the Midwest would do the same thing. Whether it's NYC Tech bros displacing midwest locals or Americans displacing SEA locals, gentrification works the same way, bringing higher purchasing power into lower cost markets. International moves just amplify it through currency strength, but the mechanism is identical.   And plenty of countries welcome expats who integrate respectfully, resentment builds when they form isolated bubbles and drive up costs. Preserving American culture isn't a priority for me personally. Different people value different things. Fixing systemic political problems takes decades with no guarantee of success. I'm not willing to sacrifice my life hoping things improve generations from now. Individual optimization makes more sense than betting on collective action.  If I do move internationally, I'm committed to doing it as ethically as possible. I'm learning the language, genuinely respect the culture and people, and love the food and lifestyle, it's not just about cheap living. I'm not planning to bring millions and live lavishly above locals, just enough to survive comfortably while working on my own businesses at my own pace. I want to integrate and contribute, not just extract value and live in an expat bubble. It won't eliminate the economic impact entirely, but it's better than the worst case digital nomad behavior.

commentText: I think American society has been broken in a lot of ways for a long time, but prior generations were willing to ignore it because they could get into the social contract. Go to school, get a job, buy a house, have kids. The path was set and it was easy to achieve. Gen Z is being excluded from the contract and is now questioning the whole thing.  I also worked my up thru community college (working full time in retail jobs) to a good job. I'm still nowhere near being able to afford a good house. And yet multiple times I've been told by boomers and Gen X "you're just lazy, you don't work hard enough, you don't deserve it". They got theirs and they just don't care. Gen Z is going to have to fix this broken system on our own.

commentText: Most of the companies who say they are "hiring" aren't actually hiring.  Companies get tax breaks if they're in the process of hiring new people. So what they do is post fake openings for jobs that dont actually exist. Then, they throw all the applications into the trash, take down the opening, and repost it a few weeks later.  So a lot of the "job openings" arent actually real.

commentText: I have adhd and normally pay about $20-$40 for my medication at the pharmacy because of my insurance. My doctor gives me a 3 month supply at a time so I only need to go in once every 3 months to get my medications refilled. I just looked up how much that would cost if I didn't have insurance, and it's insane. Depending on which pharmacy I go to in my area, I will be looking to spend between $160 and $911 for my meds. That's absolutely ridiculous, especially when I know it does not cost nearly that much to manufacture each individual pill.  Recently I've been wanting to leave my job because my managers have been being more and more disrespectful, mean, and overall assholes to me and my crew, and I don't want to live like that. Every hour I'm at work is another hour that feels like I'm suffering. I can't leave because I'll lose my insurance and therefore access to my medications. The job market is absolutely atrocious for people my age right now, and I have this profound sense of being stuck and nothing will ever get better. If I could afford to I'd love to just dip out and move to a different country where the people aren't depressed all the time, but that shit is also INCREDIBLY expensive. I also shouldn't have to move away and leave all my friends and family behind just to live in a place that doesn't suck shit every single day

commentText: I'd like to remind everyone that in 1919, the Dodge Brothers sued the Ford Motor Co. for not passing all of their profits onto shareholders. Ford was passing much of their profits on to the employees with large bonuses, and consumers by offering many promotions and sales that were actually valuable and directly helpful to the consumer. This changed when the courts sided with Dodge Bros and ruled that the fiduciary duty of a corporation is to pass profits to the shareholders.

commentText: Class of 2020 here! Grew up absolutely fascinated with computers and technology, knew that I wanted to get into the IT field since I was maybe 13. Took about a year off after graduation just to breath, then went to a local technical school and took on the ensuing debt. Graduated 2023 and I have had exactly one actual in-field job not thanks to my education, but because of a previous connection I had. And unfortunately, that job didn't work out.  The worst part is I have friends who didn't go to higher education who aren't even hearing back from traditionally entry-level jobs like fast-food service. Higher education feels like a scam because of the amount of debt you go in and with no grantee that you'll get an in-field job. However, if you don't have a degree, you are completely screwed unless you have connections or get extremely lucky. I think it's so absurd that I, someone who is in debt, still living with my parents and barely motivated enough to get out of bed in the morning, am the lucky one among my friend group.

commentText: 7:25 As a developer, I can assure you that â€œspeed of code writtenâ€ is not a valuable metric in of itself.  Has the code been properly tested? If an AI was used to generate those tests, were the tests manually reviewed thoroughly? Ensuring that it didnâ€™t make a suite full of garbage tests, just so that it can get close to a 100% pass rate. A multiplier of this makes work more challenging, not easy.  Is it maintainable? Did it make a bunch of unnecessary abstractions that make it difficult to understand? Again, a multiplier of this makes the work more challenging, not easy.  Did it generate code using outdated dependencies that have been subjected to numerous security issues? This multiplies the number of security risks, which again, makes the work more challenging.  I understand that the speed of delivery is important. However, if you develop at a speed where you disregard these concerns, theyâ€™ll come back to bite you eventually and cause greater harm than if you took the correct precautions in the first place.

videoTitle: The AI rollout is here - and it's messy | FT Working It
videoDescription: Businesses are spending hundreds of billions of dollars on AI for the workplace. But getting employees to use the tools to their full ...
commentText: Just to make things clear, what companies are calling AI now, is just LLM (Large Language model) that is good at mimic human writing. Like your autocorrect keyboard but is trained at every text that has ever been written, not just your text messages. However, it really doesn't understand what is saying, it is almost like a parrot, just because it repeats what you say it doesn't mean the parrot understand what it is saying. Whether LLMs or diffusion model or image/video generation, don't understand the world, they don't understand physics, they don't understand chemistry or biology. They are just good at mimicking what is has been trained on. That doesn't mean that they are not useful, but at it's core it just mimicking what it saw with some randomness sprinkled on top to it doesn't end up repeating everything it saw word for word.

commentText: While AI tools can be helpful for certain development tasks, claims of 75% productivity increases likely don't reflect the reality of most software engineering teams working on complex, real-world applications. Simple projects might see bigger gains, but enterprise software development involves much more than just writing code. It's worth noting that AI assistants are tools that augment human work rather than replace human judgment and expertise. They can speed up some tasks like boilerplate code generation or debugging, but they don't independently "think" or understand context the way humans do. They're pattern-matching systems that work best with clear instructions. The relationship between AI coding tools and business outcomes like sales isn't straightforward either. Even if developers write code faster, that doesn't automatically translate to more revenueâ€”product-market fit, user experience, and business strategy still matter most. Better prompts definitely improve AI outputs, but they're not a magic solution. The quality of results still depends heavily on the problem's complexity, the human's expertise in reviewing and integrating the output, and realistic expectations about what these tools can and cannot do.

commentText: Today layoffs have nothing to do with AI. Sure LLMs (and the following models) are going to involves layoffs, but in the 10 next years. The number of organisations who are *already* able to replace humans with AI is very very small. Today layoffs are more about a global crisis, with inflation, a US president disturbing the world economy, the invasion of Ukraine, climate warming (just the beginning...), etc. So sure, AI will take jobs, as robots did in factories decades ago, but it just means more time for other activities, at least with the proper political regime (not all for the already most wealthy).

commentText: I want to make one correction to the lady around 9:17. The word you're looking for is "automated tracking system" or ATS. Examples include Workday and Talio. These are not new and as a 32 year old when I graduated when I was younger I encountered them as well (circa 2015-2016). ATS systems have nothing to do with the impact ChatGPT and generative AI has on the labour market and it's not helpful to confuse the two. People have been complaining about ATS systems for a very long time, even before ChatGPT and the like existed. The time when humans would review applications was a very long time ago, like maybe 2010 or thereabouts.

commentText: Varun nailed the distinction â€“ if you're just 'translating' instructions into code, you're obsolete.  In my view, we are seeing a split in the dev market: 'Orchestration' (translating specs to code) is now an AI commodity. The only safe career path left is 'Validation' (auditing the AI's work for security, logic, and scale).  I recently broke down this specific transition (from 'Translator' to 'Validator') in my podcast (The Spark and The Forge, Ep 78) for any devs trying to survive this 13% drop in entry-level roles.

commentText: AI isn't taking jobs, it's AI speculation that's taking jobs. AI has generally underperformed everywhere it's been implemented, with studies generally showing it makes workers less efficient (which the media should know, considering the high-profile embarrassments they've had). As the for the hype, it's largely driven by a mix of speculation, advertising/marketing, and bad assumptions about generative AI's current capabilities. All that said, the reporter(s) and pundit(s) for this story could easily lose their jobs to AI without anything of value being lost because their claims involve as much hallucination and shoddy information as AI.

commentText: I'm not really surprised. People need jobs to survive. Plus in many companies, high job positions are already filled by older generation of people who cannot afford to retire because this country has allowed large corporations to absorb pensions back to give CEOs the chance to give themselves bonuses, adding to their already inflated salaries.   So what are people going to do? I'm not surprised that this is happening. I'm definitely not gonna be surprised when the existence of the "entry level" positions would go away in the future. Since, companies doesn't want to give pensions to their retirement age employees, 20-something year olds taking entry level positions are gonna have to stay there almost indefinitely. Which is gonna cause a stop in hiring new employees, killing the future of the potential workforce that's coming up in less than a decade. It's already bad now. We have kids still in college & still in highschool who have less than 4 years left so that they'll be in the workforce too.  This is gonna cause a spike in homelessness, poverty related crimes etc. All because this country has continued to fail us over & over again. This is way worse than the Great Depression. This is gonna be something than this country hasn't seen before. Now since Donald Trump has fired the Head of The Department of Labor, actual statistics of what's happening & what's going to happen in the future will not be shown on paper. Causing a further rift between what our elected officials see about how bad the economy is for many Americans vs how Americans see & feel strain of this in our everyday lives.

commentText: The problem is the survey questions/data and videos like these are designed to produce a certain narrative.  It's always a spin that, while perhaps not overt, it covertly puts the blame on the workers and middle managers.  The fact is all wage earners below the C-suite are simply not getting a worthwhile piece of the pie.  Not even close, and that's why people are disengaged, directionless, less than maximum productivity, and essentially every other bad thing.  If you want change, the only viable option is unionization and those unions need to be the ones doing survey's and controlling the narrative.  Cost of living went up...pay more.  You want more productivity...pay more.  You want me to be fully engaged...pay more.  You want me to use the new AI tool that will eventually take my job...pay more.  This all comes back to pay more.  Everything else is just nonsense excuses to avoid paying wage earners their fair share.

commentText: The housing collapse was the first crack. Banks gambled, collapsed, and got taxpayer bailouts. Executives handed themselves bonuses with public money while the public paid the price. Occupy Wall Street tried to push back, but nothing truly changed. The same players stayed in power. The rules stayed rigged.  Now we are living through the next phase. Mass layoffs, ghost jobs, AI filters, and stagnant wages are everywhere. Profits soar, shareholders celebrate, and executives cash out while telling workers to be grateful for scraps.  Meritocracy is gone. Optics replaced it. Corporate success is no longer built on value or skill, but on who can perform the best image while cutting the people they parade for PR. Behind the curtain, the human element is gone, and the faÃ§ade grows thicker.  AI is not the enemy. The real danger is AI CEOs and executives who treat technology as their personal crown. They are not building; they are competing to out-narcissist each other, blinded by ego and greed. Investors fuel this arms race because it spikes their portfolios, no matter the long-term damage. Behind closed doors, the C-suite and shareholders pat themselves on the back while carving out what remains of the middle class.  This is not about politics. It is about power. The ultra-wealthy control the levers and have no interest in building a system that works for anyone else. This is the second reckoning. The first was the manufacturing carve-out that gutted entire communities. This one is a technological carve-out, and its effects are already eroding the workforce from within.  If you feel invisible, you are not imagining it. This market is not broken; it is built to extract and discard. Until people stop accepting optics for progress and demand substance, the machine will keep grinding through generation after generation.  The ultra-wealthy will not save us. They are too busy competing to see who can burn it down the fastest.

commentText: I closed my laptop two minutes into an interview. Posted as remote, anywhere in my province. The interviewer asked how my day was going so far, I said something about the weather in my city that day. They froze, then said something about needing to be onsite (which was 4hrs away) once a week. I reminded her the posting only indicated remote work and she apologized for it being incorrect. I mentioned that I had another application pending for the same org, and wondered if she knew anything about the status of it. When I told her the position title, she told me it was a duplicate posting just worded slightly different. I told her there was a $35k difference between the two job listings. She froze again and I left the call shaking my head. That was one of only five interviews I got out of 70+ applications in a year.

commentText: I drove 45 minutes and showed up to a job interview and told the people at the front desk that I was here for an interview.  They looked confused and asked me for the name of the person I was supposed to be interviewing.  I gave them the name.  A little bit later, that person came out and we went into a private room to start talking.  They told me that the job was "recently filled" and there wasn't anything currently open anymore, but that they liked my resume enough that they wanted to talk to me in-person for "potential future opportunities".  At this point, I was seething so hard, I wanted to yell at them for wasting my time or say something snarky to this hiring manager.  But I practiced self control and played along and did my best as if the job was open, all the while rage was boiling in my stomach;  I didn't want to burn any bridges in-case this company is my last resort down the line and they do have something open in the far future.    But what a waste of my time, my whole day was wasted on this that could have been spent searching/applying for more jobs or preparing for a real interview.

commentText: I'm 50 and I live in Denmark. commentText: Iâ€™m from a small community in New England. I used to think that one day Iâ€™d want to get a fancy corporate job in a city like New York or Boston. But now the entire process of getting one of those jobs is sounding less and less appealing, let alone realistic. I work at a public library in my hometown and never had to worry about competing with hundreds of other candidates, getting ghosted by the company, or getting interviewed by AI. The person I emailed my resume to is the same person who interviewed me and who is now my boss. I used to think we were at a disadvantage living in a smaller place, with fewer opportunities, but now I see we are actually so lucky to have a job market with real people and real jobs.

commentText: Hearing to tailor the resume for each job posting, on top of already tailoring the cover letter for each job post, sounds fine in a small scale. But is unbelievably exhausting in reality. A lot of us applying to hundreds of jobs are doing that. It feels like it's just a pure numbers game rather than anything else. No matter how perfect a resume, cover letter, skills/abilities you have, experience history, etc., none of that seems to matter in the grand scheme of things. It's either you know someone, are able to know someone (and they're also willing to give you the time of day, which many aren't), or you have the willpower and patience to send out an infinite number of applications just for the hope of hearing back from a small few. Sorry if this sounds defeatist, I do appreciate the discussion and the advice, but this just eats away at you to where you just don't feel human anymore.

commentText: don't you need junior employees to get to senior employees?  It's like the industry is eating itself.  The ones that are senior didn't just get there on academic training or self teaching.  You have to be in these roles, you have to see how all of the moving parts fit together.  Even before this AI boom do you know anyone who would say that whatever their HR was doing to find qualified candidates was just going so gangbusters well that they should be studied?  I think every single one of us has seen somebody hired for a position that can't even handle simple tasks on their own.  My favorite is having to train a PHD that just got hired and can't even troubleshoot equipment they have only heard mentioned in papers.  They've actually never interacted with some of these things and only know the results.  It's like expecting someone to read a book about dovetail joinery and then immediately expecting them to make perfect dovetail joints.

commentText: My husband has been hunting for a job for over a year. He has 20 years of experience in his field, plus the additional training, certifications and experience from taking over the responsibilities of people who left or were fired from his last company.  None of it matters. He's submitted hundreds of applications. He's had two interviews. One interview was promising, with multiple rounds, but they ghosted him without even a rejection email.  The other interview was for a job that was really 5 positions in one, for $16/hr.  That's it.  He recently found a batch of good positions at a well known company in our city. He even has a friend who just left that company- those positions are all going to be filled internally.   I don't know how he does it. It's soul crushing to go through the indignity of this system. The job market is fundamentally broken.

It feels like such a roundhouse kick to the face to have spent all this time and money training for jobs that you cant get or keep. We were sold the lie of go to post secondary, get entry level work experience and youâ€™ll be cruising along life just fine. And as adults we have no idea how to prepare the next generations for what the future of work will look like. One of the major reasons why less and less people are having kids, and where people are choosing to have kids, they are having far less because it is hard to see a viable present and future for them.

commentText: I've been to Walmart for 2 years.  It's tough. Even at minimum wage, I had management riding me nonstop to be faster every night I worked.  This was a minimum wage job, yet they treated it like Amazon warehouse where they keep pushing you every day you work to be faster and do more in less time.  I was written up for the dumbest stuff.  One night I was stocking I had 4 mixed pallets on one end of my aisle and 1 pallet of just my stuff at the other.  Management called me to the office and said they're writing me up for not working because that 1 pallet is still sitting there at the end of my aisle.  I explained he obviously didn't see the other 4 mixed pallets which my stuff on top buried everyone else's stuff underneath so I was trying to move that off and stock it because you're not supposed to leave boxes strewn across the floor.  Management said they didn't see it and apologized, but said they still had to write me up because they had already called me to the office and it would look bad on them for pulling me away from my work for nothing.  That was back in 2015.  I'm sure Walmart is a lot harder today.  I changed jobs went to a grocery store doing minimum wage.  The grocery store refused to provide benefits, so everyone was scheduled less than 20hrs/wk.  I had just graduated from college (in my 30s) and had 10 years of customer service/retail exp under my belt and they treat me like I'm below the high school kids they were hiring that sit around drinking gatorade and playing on their phones.  Anyway, minimum wage jobs for the past 10 years couldn't afford an apartment, and I'm sure nowadays they can't either.  My old apartment up near the university was across the street from the grocery store used to be $600/month.  Today, it's practically doubled in rent, and the neighborhood now has a lot of problems with drugs.  A nice apartment in that university town you're looking at paying $3k+ for a single.  I left to China in 2019 because I couldn't find a job with my BA degree from the university right there in that town.  The Career Center at the university kept telling me to apply for GEICO insurance because they just opened new offices and needed help.  Her husband worked there.  I applied and went through round 1 of interviews 3 times.  They always ghost me after that.  So one day I called GEICO and asked to speak with the HR because I really wanted to know yes or no whether I got the job.  They told me the HR will be working on Thursdays.  I called back on Thursday, and the HR was out of town down in Florida on a family vacation.  I'm sitting there like, "you could have told me she was going to be out of the office this thursday, call back next thursday, but you didn't."  Felt like they just were making up stories and the job postings on Indeed might have been fake to appear like they're hiring when they were not.  I was also upset with the career center for not helping me find work.  You would think the school would be helping graduates find work because it'd show that their university degrees actually have value!  Instead, they didn't help me.  I had to go out and find my own job teaching in China.  I wish I could end there, but covid started 6 months after I arrived.  Their visa situation was chaos and my visa expired during a lockdown, so I couldn't get another work visa and I had to return home.  Now I'm jobless, living at home, taking care of my grandmother that was recently diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease.  If she goes into a nursing home, we'll lose the house.  I've tried finding work when I came home from China, but employers just laugh me out the door.  The only type of job hiring right now is heavy industrial, and I don't have any heavy industrial skills.  I'm an academic, not a tradesman.  You say the job market is on the edge?  I'd say it's already collapsed when even young generation are struggling to find entry level positions and salaries everywhere are not keeping up with inflation and the rising cost of living.

A combination of ageism, sexism, and AI has kept me unemployed, and I am applying for disability due to several chronic illnesses now. I finally paid off my student loans after 24 years in 2024, when I was 48 years old. My husband is keeping our family of four afloat with his pest control job, but if not for landlords who I swear were sent from Heaven to help us, we would be homeless. $26/hour isn't enough to support a family of four in market-rate housing. Even with the blessing of affordable rent, it's 50% of our income. I don't know what's going to happen when medical insurance goes up, we are walking a financial tightrope

videoTitle: Nobody Wants To Live In Upstate New York

commentText: I live in Buffalo. When I was offered a chance to take a job here 26 years ago, I told my wife "Why would we want to move to Buffalo?". She's a Detroit girl, so she was all about it. Then I met the people, saw the nature, experienced the culture, and found a home. We love it here. We own an old house in the Elmwood Village part of the city within walking distance of pretty much everything we need. Until I retired a few years ago I rode my bike to work. As for the winters, we joined a year round hiking challenge a few years ago, and winter has become the best time of year to be outside. Some storms can be brutal, so it pays to be prepared and to never take the weather for granted. And, yes you need a car - an all wheel drive is preferable. We live on Subaru Street. Finally, my son and daughter-in-law lived in the Albany area for years, and we always combined visits with hiking the Adirondacks. Itâ€™s a great area too.

commentText: There is a lot more,, and I mean, A LOT MORE, to upstate NY than the Capital Region. Some of it is nice, some not so nice. Some is pretty depressed, but there are some really great places, and compared to a lot of other states it is cheap. Taxes?  You get what you pay for.  A lot of the tax money goes to the schools. The rest goes to the town and county, to maintain everything they have to maintain, and pay the workers. There are a ton of colleges in NY too and every county has a Community College, where if you don't have a lot of money, you can begin your college career, then transfer.

videoTitle: Nobody Wants To Live In Upstate New York
videoDescription: Love exploring Upstate? Get the monthly guide I only share by email â†’ https://gabsmall.com/newsletter/ Born in Saratoga, living ...
commentText: I come from the tropics, a place full of islands with crystal-clear waters, white sandy beaches, and warm weather year-round. But after moving to the U.S., I fell in love with the Northeast. The beauty hereâ€”the changing seasons, rolling hills, meadows, lakes, and creeksâ€”completely won me over. Whatâ€™s not to love?  I know winters can be tough, especially for the elderly who might not have support, but aside from that, I donâ€™t see many downsides to living in this region. Iâ€™ve heard plenty of people complain about the cold and gloomy winters after moving away, but honestly, Iâ€™ve never seen it as a problem. I actually love the winter sceneryâ€”bare trees, quiet landscapes, and that peaceful, frozen stillness.  To me, constant heat all year round feels monotonous. I enjoy watching the vibrant colors of fall, feeling cozy by the woodstove while snow falls outside, seeing flowers bloom in spring, and hearing crickets as summer approaches. Those small, seasonal moments are things I never got to experience back in the tropics, and I truly cherish them now.  What also makes the Northeast special is its close proximity to major cities like New York City and Boston, along with an abundance of top-tier universities and colleges. This attracts a diverse, young crowd and helps drive innovation, culture, and the economy. Add to that the regionâ€™s rich supply of fresh waterâ€”something thatâ€™s becoming more valuable every yearâ€”and it really feels like the best of both worlds.

commentText: I've lived from Alaska to Texas to Colorado and now I've been in upstate NY for almost four years. I absolutely love it here. Not as gloomy as the PNW nor as dry as Colorado. It's WAY cheaper to live and unlike most places that are "cheap" the pay is good too. Lots of great food. If you're into nature it's a dream. If you want big city vibes, go to NYC, it's only a train ride away. My daughter lives in Rochester and I'm now in the country but lived in Syracuse for three years. Crime exists everywhere and if you're stuck living in a really poor area it's going to suck just like any city. The people are amazing. And as climate change keeps getting worse, it's going to be the place to live.

videoTitle: Nobody Wants To Live In Upstate New York
videoDescription: Love exploring Upstate? Get the monthly guide I only share by email â†’ https://gabsmall.com/newsletter/ Born in Saratoga, living ...
commentText: I was born and raised in Brooklyn where I lived for 55 years. I began visiting childhood friends in the southern Adirondacks in 1980 and fell in love with the area. I bought my home, a small cottage built in 1936, at a tax foreclosure auction for $12,100 in 2000 (you aren't going to get a deal like that now). I purchased additional land next to me a couple of years later. Mind you, I have lived in only 2 apartments during my 55 years in Brooklyn, this is the only that I have ever bought. The town I live in has just under 800 residents, but that population more than doubles come the summer. We are rural, no municipal water, gas or sewer. If you're rich you heat with electric, otherwise we heat with wood, propane, oil, coal or wood pellets. Most heat with wood, like me. Winters are BRUTAL, but I knew that before I bought the house. I moved up full time in the Spring of 2013. Public transportation sucks for sure. I don't drive, so it's a taxi down the mountain to the shopping areas and doctors in the county. It's great that Walmart delivers, but if I want stuff from other grocery stores then it's a taxi or a friend to drive me. Doctors are issue, we do have a small hospital in the county as well as adjoining counties but most of the clinics associated with the hospitals have NP's or PA's. If you need to see a specialist, you could wait upwards of 2 months for an appointment. Property and school taxes are OUT OF CONTROL. New York State mandates are roughly half or more of the property tax. Medicaid is the biggest mandate along with Welfare and another listed as "Other". Counties must pay 25% of mandated Medicaid and Welfare programs in their county. The more you hand out; the more property owners have to pay. You do get a break on school taxes if your property is your primary residence and if you are 65+ you get a much bigger break. But depending on the size of the school district (number of schools) and whether or not they are union schools, the school tax can be very big. I am surrounded by forested land, which I like, but living in a rural area does come with certain dangers like falling trees and wildlife that wants to have you for its next meal. Bear, coyotes, bobcats, and fox are common here. A few days ago, I looked out my kitchen window into my yard and some something strange. When I went outside, there were the carcasses of 2 turkeys and feathers all over the place. I do not leave the house without my Glock. Lots of people have been posting photos on Facebook of bear and coyotes that their security cameras have captured. We do have crime in the town. Mostly burglaries fueled by drug addiction. Lots of overdoses, some fatal every month. Well-paying jobs are hard to find, if you are lucky to get a state or federal job then you will get paid well. Local and county jobs pair a fair wage but not as much as the state or feds. All in all, this is a much better life than what I had in Brooklyn. Here I can set up a target in my back yard and do some target practice and nobody will complain. If I hear gunshots, I don't have to dive on the floor and get away from the windows. Politically, the town is Conservative with Republicans outnumbering Democrats 9-1. The county is predominately Republican with one location being more Democrats and that is the area that has the most problems. Before you decide to move upstate you really have to do your homework. I have seen, since the pandemic, people buying homes (overpriced) and moving up here only to decide to sell and move out after a year or two. Winters are brutal, this isn't NYC or Long Island. Residents shoot guns and hunt. The pizza SUCKS. If you want gluten free you are not going to find it here. If you are Left in your political beliefs, you are outnumbered. If that bothers you buy a place in the overpriced Catskills.

commentText: Little different perspective. Fifth generation upstate New Yorker. Family moved to Mid Atlantic region when Dad got out of the service in the late 50s. He took a DOD job, Mom stayed home with 7 kids. Mid Atlantic was a great move for Dad and the family with all of the opportunities. We always vacationed every summer back to NY State and when I got married in the late 70s my wife and then our family continued to vacation and visit family in the Upstate Region. About 20 years ago I rediscovered the North Country and we spent a lot of time there. As we got close to retirement we started looking for a second/ vacation home in the region for the summer months. Home prices were extremely reasonable even Lake and Riverfront homes. Unfortunately the multiple taxes that come with home ownership are utterly ridiculous for what little you see in return. My taxes on a million dollar home in the Mid Atlantic are high vs the national average but nowhere near as high as the areas we looked at.  We were looking at roughly the same taxes on a 400K home in the N Country. So instead of buying we rent for three summer months on the St Lawrence for what we would spend on taxes if we bought. Makes no sense to me.

videoTitle: Nobody Wants To Live In Upstate New York
videoDescription: Love exploring Upstate? Get the monthly guide I only share by email â†’ https://gabsmall.com/newsletter/ Born in Saratoga, living ...
commentText: I lived in Southern California, North Carolina, and now the Albany area, and I think that it is a well-kept secret, personally. I agree a lot with your comments, the people are friendly, and you have access to beautiful lakes and mountains all around you. It's also nice to be close to NYC, Boston, and Montreal, if you want to catch a show or get a taste of a big city. As for when I lived in NC, definitely a better place for younger people and more job opportunities, but unless you golf, go to church, or are a college basketball fan, you might find it rather boring and dull and the summers were pretty brutal with the heat. Everyone goes to the beach on the weekends, which is a 2-hour drive, but do I miss it, not really. SoCal is definitely materialistic and way too expensive for my taste. Your comments were spot on, and I suppose every place has its pros and cons, but you have to find out for yourself what you are looking for.

commentText: I graduated in 2022 and the first few months were rough. I was sending out hundreds of applications every week and barely hearing anything back. Half are definitely ghost listings, I eventually picked up work at a small art gallery in NYC, then finally landed a spot at a tech startup. I thought things were turning around, but it was the same story everywhere. Every place I worked found a way to squeeze more out of me while paying less. Long hours, weekends, holidays; none of it mattered. And when it was convenient, they let me go. I only lasted 6 months at the tech startup, laid off due to AI.  At some point I just hit a wall. I figured if I was going to work this hard, it should be for something I actually care about. So I walked away from the mess and went all-in on aviation. Now Iâ€™m in flight school, working toward becoming a commercial pilot. Airlines at least offer real protections, solid benefits, and a career path that isnâ€™t built on constant undercutting. Best decision Iâ€™ve made.

commentText: Overall a good video, but a couple of points I would like to add:  1) While yes, the unemployment rate is currently at about 4%, that doesnâ€™t accurately reflect how many people are unemployed. It just says how many people, who are eligible for unemployment benefits, are actually receiving unemployment. If you quit your job (due to a toxic work environment), did not seek unemployment, gave up certifying for unemployment, your unemployment ran out, or otherwise didnâ€™t qualify for unemployment / currently on unemployment but are still an adult before the retirement age who isnâ€™t currently working, you arenâ€™t counted towards the unemployment rate. That said, even if we assume that rate is twice as high (like 8% the eligible working population) which is overly generous, the point in the video still stands, but that would help explain why (1) itâ€™s hard to get a job and (2) the perception of others without jobs being fairly high.  2) The unemployment cycle is extremely real. In addition to whatâ€™s mentioned in the video head hunters and job recruiters extremely favor those who are currently working than those who arenâ€™t. They often assume that those who are unemployed lost their job because theyâ€™re incompetent, or not good to work with, and that theyâ€™re currently unemployed because theyâ€™re lazy. Furthermore, the longer youâ€™re unemployed, the bigger the gap in your resume is making you easier to pass over by recruiters. Do what he says in the video and everything you do while unemployed in terms of training and self development, put it in your resume to fill the gap. It makes you look like you werenâ€™t sitting on your thumbs just waiting for the next job to fall into your lap.  3) You can do everything right and still be unemployed for 6 months - 1.5 years. It sucks, but you have to remember itâ€™s a numbers game and that this is ultimately a matter of luck (in essentially being in the right place at the right time). All you can do is increase your odds (and this video does do a good job at telling you how to do that), but be aware that you arenâ€™t alone, and others have been in this situation youâ€™re in or are currently going through it themselves. As he says, just keep at it (itâ€™s all you can do at the end of the day anyway).

commentText: To any job seekers reading this comment: donâ€™t give up on online job applications. It is very true that online job boards are in a bad state right now. Fake job listings, thousands of applicants, and companies using ai to deny resumes, not to mention having to make online accounts for every company that uses workday among other pains that you are no doubt aware of. But I assure you in the sea of thousands of job listings there is one out there for you. I recently secured a job with a company that uses workday after months of applying and almost calling it quits. I know how bad the struggle is but you should never stop applying. But most importantly donâ€™t just apply to every job you think is a good fit for you. Make sure your resume and cv are tweaked so hr or the hiring manager can understand what you could bring to the job.

commentText: Scapegoating is the act of unfairly blaming an individual or group for problems, often to deflect blame from the real source of the issue. It can involve individuals blaming individuals, individuals blaming groups, groups blaming individuals, or groups blaming groups. This practice can be a way to release tension or frustration by directing negative emotions towards an innocent party.  Here's a more detailed explanation: Deflection of blame: Scapegoating shifts the focus away from the actual cause of a problem, often to an individual or group that is perceived as vulnerable or different.  Release of tension: It can be a way for individuals or groups to release pent-up anger, frustration, or anxiety by projecting it onto the scapegoat.  Social phenomenon: Scapegoating can be a social phenomenon where a group targets an individual or another group to blame for their problems, sometimes to maintain power structures or reinforce group identity.  Examples: Scapegoating can be seen in various contexts, from families where one child is blamed for all the household issues, to larger social groups blaming minority groups for economic problems.  Consequences: Scapegoating can lead to prejudice, discrimination, and even violence against the targeted individual or group.

commentText: I'm in South FL.  Construction boom everywhere.  Port St. Lucie, Ft. Pierce, Vero Beach, Melbourne, Viera, etc.  I am a concrete mixer truck driver.  Too much work. 60-70 hours a week on 5-6 days a week.  I'm exhausted.  There's lots of work here for anyone interested.  Concrete companies are even willing to hire and train new graduates from CDL school.  Starting pay around $22,23.  Upper end $28/hr. All the concrete companies are competing against one another for drivers.  Hard work, long hours but if you need to make ends meet, have dependents, need benefits like health insurance, this might be an option.  Hope this helps someone.

commentText: Sorry folks. But WHAT took you SO damn long to realize this??? NOW you know that people like her are NOT lying and this is NOT a damn myth! It's been reality for years. It is funny that people ARE NOW realizing this harsh truth about the job market when I have KNOWN this for WAY more than a decade now but was told "you're lazy," "you're not trying hard enough," "you got to do this and that," "you're not looking in the right places," "you're not applying for the right jobs," "maybe you're not applying for enough jobs," "maybe you're a little too thin or fat for them to consider you," "maybe you're too attractive or ugly for them to take you," "you should just get a different degree,"  "maybe you were overdressed or underdressed at interviews," and blah blah blah.    Instead of telling us "little people" to repeatedly fix and update skills, resumes, cover letters, curriculum histories, interviewing techniques, our looks, and all that stuff when we ALREADY do, the "bigger guys" need stop being picky! Entry/junior level jobs used to only require a high school diploma and no experience. Now for the SAME jobs, they want years of experience with or without a degree. But that's not how it's supposed to be! Entry level is supposed to be for college students, new graduates, low income people like us bettering ourselves, people with no work experience, and for people changing careers. Those positions are NOT supposed to be for experienced workers! Only intermediate and professional level jobs are for the experienced!     They cannot it have it both ways: They tell people to "go get a job," "you should work like the rest of us," and "don't rely on taxpayers for welfare." But, they are the ones who don't want to hire the same people and that's why those same people have to get on and be on welfare. Plus, if we want to restore dignity in merit and hard work again, then the nepotism, favoritism, sororities, fraternities, insides ties, and country club ties ALSO need to stop!!!! AND EDIT: Stop the outsourcing of jobs too. Don't get into more wars that ruin the economy, don't create more recessions that ruin the country, and don't let inflation get sky high. Those are other reasons why the job economy sucks and why our generation isn't as well off as prior ones.

commentText: There's nothing "weird" about the economy. Since 2008, the top 10% have been the economic engine (50% of GDP) while the bottom 80% have been losing economic power, going into greater debt, losing upward mobility, saving less, etc.. This is called a "K-shaped" economy, where a handful of families effectively control all of the gains. In old Europe, this was called a feudal system. The "lords" (oligarchs) now control tax and fiscal and regulatory policy for their net benefit, not for the greater good of the county. In other words, there is no longer a level socioeconomic playing field, like we had 1945-1980. Really, all you need to know is that 94% of the 2024 presidential campaign funding came from just 150 oligarch families. Full stop.

commentText: This episode perfectly captures why the "vibes" feel so off right now. A few thoughts on the systemic issues Joe and Tracy touched on: â€¢ The Tariff Trade-off: We need to stop looking at tariffs just as "revenue." The real danger isn't whether they fund the government, but how they act as a wrench in the gears of the global supply chain. If they make it harder to move goods, they create a "scarcity inflation" that hits consumers regardless of what the federal deficit looks like. â€¢ AI vs. Infrastructure: The scale of the AI buildout is staggering, but as noted at, itâ€™s a massive drain on our power grid. We have to ask: is it a good use of our nation's limited energy and top-tier engineering talent to fuel a "circular money machine" that mostly generates "slop", while our physical infrastructure and climate goals are sidelined? â€¢ Solving the Vibe-cession: The disconnect between "good data" and "bad feelings" comes down to precarity. Even when the economy is "growing," people are terrified of the "life-ruining" event of losing a job. We don't just need growth; we need a baseline of economic security that doesn't disappear the moment a tech bubble pops. â€¢ The Goal of the Economy: Weâ€™ve moved from an economy that builds things to one that functions as a "comparison engine". Until policy shifts from managing financial abstractions back to managing our actual resourcesâ€”labor, energy, and materialsâ€”the "vibe" isn't going to improve.

commentText: On consumer sentiment not tracking with Income you significantly failed to recognize that FRED's calculation of personal income is based on a national average WITH investment income included. This does not represent the average persons income. Investments are overwhelmingly owned by and benefiting the wealthy - particularly after taxes. Investment income has a much lower capital gains tax rate of 0 to 20%. However a regular wage earners has a much higher federal income tax rate of up to 37% as well as state (0 - 13.2%) and local income taxes (0 - 3.88%), Medicare taxes (1.45 - 2.35%), social security taxes (6.2%). None of these impact investment income. The lack of significant investment income has greatly depressed actual and perceived income for anyone depending on a paycheck or even a social security check. This is the reason consumer sentiment has taken a nose dive. FRED's personal disposable income value does not represent most Americans actual income. You can't explain the divergence between these two charts because they have little correlation to each other - especially if one is a low income earner with no investments, such as 40% of Americans according to a 2025 Gallup Poll.

commentText: Financilization, Financilization, Financilization. This can't be overstated enough. The economy you're seeing right now has literally been predicted by both Marxist and Post-Keynesian economists for *decades* This idea that everything is chaos and no one can tell what's going to happen is just starting to feel frustrating at this point. What's going to happen is actually far more predictable than you think. If we assume business as usual and no major economic reforms we can expect: Increased wealth inequality, increased asset inflation, Corporate consolidation, Private Equity and Shadow Banking prevalence increasing, further disconnect between financial markets and the real economy, trajectory towards a Super Star economy (Two tier economy), increased Zombification, Artificially suppressed interest rates, trends toward stagflation, atomization and alienation, relative deprivation and increased social instability.  The list goes on and on. It's starting to get tiring how people who follow neoclassical economic doctrine act surprised saying no one could've predicted what we're seeing today. The overall trajectory has been going this way for over 40 years and it especially supercharged after 2008. Maybe take a break from listening to what bankers on wall street are saying and listen to what critics of neoliberal capitalism has been saying forever.

videoTitle: Wake-up call from Walmart CEO: AI Is coming for every job
videoDescription: 'The Big Money Show' panelists discuss Walmart's AI.. wake-up call, warning that no job is safe as automation and robots ...
commentText: Given the rise of AI no job will be safe. People think that manual/skilled labor jobs will be safe... they won't. When was the last time you had an appliance break and got it fixed? Or took your car to a mechanic and they fixed the issue instead of simply replacing the parts? That is where we are headed to, companies are and will continue to design their products in modular "plug and play" formats. So when things break, they can be simply diagnosed and parts swapped out, those tasks can be automated. So while short term skilled jobs may stick around, but as companies continue their quest for 'efficiency' more and more tasks will become automated and the skilled workers will have worked themselves out of jobs just like tech workers programmed themselves out of employment.

commentText: I retired from the IT industry after getting training through the military, two CISCO cert schools, some cybersecurity. I applied to every IT job in the state and only got a couple interviews with no jobs. I learned that I should just create my own company. The stability of employment, even if you're broke, is way better than constantly trying to shift focus to appease meaningless entry level jobs. After doing my own thing, I am now creating c++ apps, have hired some work out, and have attracted new job offers (sorry but I'm going for gold now). Pursue your craft and jobs will become a side hustle to earn some cash.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I've come to the conclusion that I no longer want to chase after a language or framework. This changes all the time. I've also decided that I will no longer subject myself to being treated like a commodity at a cattle auction. In the end, all of this is designed to make you accept doing more for less. I think at some point we give in and accept unrealistic things because the "market demands it," or the influencer you follow or the group of followers in the bubble you're in dictates that this is the culture, technology, or method to be adopted. Yes, I went through a financial setback and had to accept working in other segments. But that didn't kill my desire to work with software. Today, I think the path is to work as an entrepreneur and consultant for small businesses, creating solutions for the region you live in or where you can work without creating a burden on your life. Another mistake I see is the industrialization of the IT workforce. We didn't start that way; we started in a garage or on a small project; we're not cattle.

Nowadays, computer techs are a commodity and the perception is of an office worker. You are disposable and can be replaced in days from thousands of other candidates in your field. Youâ€™re no more important than a file clerk.  I worked through the tech industryâ€™s best years and retired (age 60) at the tail end of that time. commentText: I'm sorry the market is so brutal.  I would suggest, in the meantime, code your own apps for sale in the app store. commentText: The tech market isn't cooked, SWE jobs are cooked.  Lots of people don't realize there's so many other technical jobs out there to apply for. Look into Solution Engineer/Solutions Consultant roles, or Implementation Consultant, or Integration Specialist.  I went the implementation Consultant route, my current role only had 100 applicants in 2 weeks, meanwhile SWE jobs get 1000 applicants in 2 days.  I know it's easy to feel doomed but there are sooo many paths out there guys. I wouldn't even be surprised if I find myself as a SWE one day.

videoTitle: AI and the Future of Work
videoDescription: This event was recorded live on October 7, 2025. Artificial Intelligence is developing at breakneck speed, causing much anxiety ...
commentText: I love the analogy of training for a marathon on roller blades - I don't think we can celebrate the fact that the electrical engineer will have a 'companion' that has access to all the best electrical knowledge available. Won't they then be dependent on that knowledge and not have their own evaluation of the situation? The line of least resistance is to 'ask AI' - I see it in my university classes all the time, any question that requires a little effort to answer is outsourced. This is what I worry about most - students losing the interest in developing their own cognitive skills.
