videoTitle: AI and the Future of Work
videoDescription: This event was recorded live on October 7, 2025. Artificial Intelligence is developing at breakneck speed, causing much anxiety ...
commentText: â€‹I want to comment only on the part about how Artificial Intelligence is changing the job market, as you asked. â€‹The experts are right to be worried. The most important point they bring up is that many companies plan to use AI to take more and more tasks away from humans. â€‹But the worry shouldn't just be about "losing your job." The real problem is the value of your work. â€‹A good salary was always safe because your skill was rare (hard to find). Now, AI makes that skill easy to find (abundant). What the machine does for free is worth very little when you do it. â€‹This is why your profession is going through Wage Compression. â€‹The solution is not just "using AI" to be faster. The solution is to pick a side in the market's new rule: â€‹The Machine's Boss: You tell the AI what it must do and what the goal is. You control the system. â€‹The Machine's Worker: You only do what the AI orders, like the example of the surgeon who becomes the machine's "steady hand". â€‹If you only follow the machine's orders, your value drops a lot. Your safety is in being the Boss.

videoTitle: AI and the Future of Work
videoDescription: This event was recorded live on October 7, 2025. Artificial Intelligence is developing at breakneck speed, causing much anxiety ...
commentText: I think the clearest enunciation of the real state of 'AI' and its dangers were by Zeynep Tufekci - although she claimed that LLMs work best with verifiable fields, such as coding. In fact, coding is just like the electrician example she used. The faults are hidden, plausible, and hard to find. There is no verification system right now - especially not the AI ones - that can find them all. And if testing does reveal a fault in outputs, finding where it resides (and working out how to fix it) are time consuming. For more specific detail, check out the MERT study on productivity harm using Claude - and note how even though coders thought they were more productive using generated code, they were less productive than similar coders not using the LLM.

commentText: Professor Chenâ€™s analysis appears markedly Americophile, privileging U.S. capitalist models and strategic narratives while overlooking the fact that Chinaâ€™s industrial ascent has relied more heavily on European engineering partnerships and Franco-German production ecosystems than on American benevolence.  It seems Professor Chen has also adopted certain American manners. His opening remarks about Dr Jeffrey Sachs struck me as unnecessarily dismissive, particularly given Dr Sachsâ€™s stature as both guest and world-renowned statesman.   Academic courtesy demands deference to invited speakers, especially one who has contributed so deeply to global development discourse. The tone at the outset reflected more of an American talk-show sparring style than the civility one expects of a university platform.  It was, in that sense, a disappointing moment for HKU Business School â€” but an unqualified triumph for Dr Sachs, whose measured and eloquent address reminded the audience of Chinaâ€™s extraordinary civilisational continuity and the constructive possibilities of its future.

commentText: Observations of now 1) Spatial compression: intertemporal and physical distance to whole of human knowledge is being eliminated; 2) Future: specialty knowledge does not exist but human assurance does; 3) Prescriptive analytics from big data breadcrumbs surveillance: TMS engineering and optimizations to augment human based applications of arts and science. 4) LLMs do not self-create -> they need a goal and object.  Fact check: 1) ChatGPT has 800 million cumulative downloads; 13-17 minutes of ave use per week, that is declining month to month;  2) human attention is scarce: free model of Facebook is being re-attempted by OpenAI: attention measured in hours of Facebook is currently 40x that of ChatGPT.   Education: arts and sciences and applied arts and sciences. Intelligence is not knowledge.   General comment: Were AI called "Artificial Knowledge" would not be as attractive: conceptual error from the beginning.  Current marketing spin repeats past spin from 1956 choice in the US academic community.
